awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute:  A high-performance GPU cluster for accelerated research
awd_abstract_narration:
The exponential growth of computing power and the emergence of high-performance computing paradigms has revolutionized all fields of science and engineering. Graphics processing unit (GPU) hardware, a type of highly parallel co-processor originally designed for generating 3D scenes in video games, has been increasingly leveraged over the last decade to dramatically accelerate scientific computing workloads. This project is for the acquisition of a GPU compute cluster consisting of 24 state-of-the-art NVIDIA Tesla V100 32 GB GPUs with fast inter-GPU communication. The resource is housed at the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB), and is accessible to researchers across campus and externally through a connection to the Pacific Research Platform/Nautilus federated systems network.

Initial research activities on the facility span the computational realm, including: a new type of multi-scale molecular simulation for predicting structural and thermodynamic properties of complex polymeric solution formulations; a materials characterization thrust involving crystal orientation indexing with real-time instrument feedback control; and the development of a scalable Neural Architecture Search framework for automatic generation of Deep Neural Network models for scientific applications of machine learning. The cluster provides a significant resource for educating the next generation of computational scientists in the latest GPU-computing techniques. Undergraduates, high-school students, and K-12 teachers will also have access via existing campus-sponsored programs: Research Experience for Teachers (RET), California Alliance for Minority Participation (CAMP), and the Center for Science and Engineering Partnerships (CSEP). These programs serve to provide training and increase the number of under-represented students in STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award provided funding for a high-performance GPU cluster hosted at The University of California, Santa Barbara with ten compute nodes containing a total of 40 NVIDIA V100 GPUs connected via NVLink. The purpose of the cluster is to serve as a campus-wide resource for research and training, broadly available by request to all members of the UCSB community. In addition, 20% of the award was allocated for the acquisition of compute nodes of the same specification made available to external users via Nautilus, a West-Coast distributed federated systems network in the Pacific Research Platform. The research activities on this cluster are primarily executed by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, thus providing training opportunities in leveraging state-of-the-art GPU clusters for high-performance computing across various computational science disciplines, including computer science, materials chemistry, and physics.

Intellectual Merit:

In the fifteen months of operation of the cluster, the resource has been instrumental in preparing research for at least 25 scientific publications across a wide variety of science disciplines, including:

  • Particle- and field-based multi-scale molecular simulations of structure and thermodynamics of polymer solution formulations.
  • Materials structure characterization with real-time crystal orientation indexing and instrument feedback control in TriBeam tomography.
  • Development of scalable Neural Architecture Search framework for automatic generation of Deep Neural Network models.
  • An auto-regressive artificial neural network and machine learning methods were used to study ocean heat content change over seven decades.
  • Atomistic simulations were used to study multi-principal element alloys with exceptional combinations of strength, ductility, and damage tolerance, and to elucidate the role of a multiplicity of dislocation movement pathways in determining mechanical properties.
  • Molecular dynamics simulations were used to study how model bacteria move through complex environments.
  • Time-domain simulations of interacting quantum systems were used to model phenomena in ultracold atom experiments.
  • Design studies were conducted for the Light Dark Matter eXperiment (LDMX), an upcoming experiment with the goal of finding dark matter in the mass range between the electron and the proton.
  • Machine-learning applications included performing neural architecture searches for skin cancer detection, learning to remove noisy images in CT-based COVID-19 diagnosis, hyperparameter tuning in object detection, and data generation in sample-deficient applications.

Broader Impact:

In the first fifteen months of operation, the UCSB-available part of the cluster had close to 100% continuous resource utilization and supported the research of 72 distinct users, of which 47 were significant users (over 10,000 computing hours). The GPU nodes added to Nautilus provide a new capability, which largely lacked GPUs with hardware double-precision floating point support. Since being made available, the Nautilus nodes have been accessed by users of OpenScienceGrid, and researchers from external institutions, including California State University, San Bernardino, The University of California, San Diego, and Carnegie-Mellon University.
